and standard tempest and alternate tempest users and tenants are also

subject: Adds Telemetry compute metrics collection scenario
commit_message:
Adds Telemetry compute metrics collection scenario

This test suite verifies that the instance metrics are properly published
and collected and have non-zero values. The verification is done via the
ceilometer API.

Waiting for the ceilometer compute agent to poll the resources is crucial,
otherwise the test suite will fail due to the fact that no samples would
be found published before checking the samples.

The ceilometer agent's polling interval should have the same value as
the test suite's polled_metric_delay. This can be done in two ways:
a. Configure tempest's polled_metric_delay, by adding the following
line in tempest.conf, in the telemetry-feature-enabled section:
    polled_metric_delay = <desired value>
b. Set the interval value in pipeline.yaml on the compute node to the
desired value and restart the ceilometer compute agent.

The second method is preferred, as the interval value defined in
pipeline.yaml is 600 seconds, which would mean each test would last
at least 10 minutes.

subject: Add aggregate look up in test_live_migrations
commit_message:
Add aggregate look up in test_live_migrations

The test_live_migration test assumes that all the compute hosts are
in the same pool. If a user has an environment where their hosts are in
different aggregates, there is a very good chance that the target host
to migrate to may not be of the same aggregate.

In that scenario, the instance may be migrated to an incompatible host,
and the test will fail for the wrong reason.

def _get_compute_hostnames was changed to first look for the current
host in all available aggregates. It returns the first aggregate host
list that has itself in it and at least one other host. To make the
method more descriptive, it was renamed to
_get_compute_hosts_in_same_aggregate.

If that search turns up empty, the method falls through to the default
lookup behavior.

subject: Reduce READ_FREQ and TIMEOUT for watch-file
commit_message:
Reduce READ_FREQ and TIMEOUT for watch-file

The watch-file option currently relies on pyinotify which makes
use of select.poll. This is eventlet incompatible so it blocks
the whole thread for TIMEOUT milliseconds every READ_FREQ seconds.

This meant that an agent/service using this option is blocked for
500 milliseconds every 1 second.

Until a non-blocking alternative can be found, this adjusts the
READ_FREQ and TIMEOUT params on the FastWatchedFileHandler to
3 and 5 respectively. So every 3 seconds, it will block for 5
milliseconds so only 0.16% of time is lost instead of 50%.

Change-Id: I6fdc0a3f1eaae39eb86440c6c4b07ca8d91f2462

subject: Neutron Routed Networks
commit_message:
Neutron Routed Networks

In Neutron, there is a effort to support routed provider networks.  A
routed network in this context, is a physical network infrastructure
that implements scaled networks by routing instead of large L2
broadcast domains.  For example, deployers may have routers at each
top-of-rack.  Instead of a single VLAN covering the deployment, each
rack would have its own VLAN and the routers will provide reachability
to the rest of the racks over L3.  Operators want Neutron to model
this like a single network.  This has implications for Nova
scheduling.

Use TinyIPA and iPXE for most Ironic jobs

Unless there's a good reason to do otherwise, we want to use TinyIPA

transfers, reducing random failures due to network issues) for all
Ironic jobs.

With tinyipa being the default ramdisk for the Ironic tempest jobs, we
now gate IPA on both tinyipa and coreos ramdisks, to prevent breakage to
a single ramdisk being merged into IPA.

This follows the pattern expected of IPA->Ironic job interaction: IPA
gates on all possible supported ramdisks, then Ironic uses the one best
suited to CI to test all jobs, with IPA gate jobs ensuring that no
changes go in that break a single ramdisk.

devstack VMs based on ramdisk chosen.

ERROR oslo_db.api InvalidPagination: Invalid pagination: `Invalid sort keys'

Which is wrong, since in this case the `InvalidPagination' is totally unrelated to the retry code.

subject: Provide fallback from ATA erase to shredding
commit_message:
Provide fallback from ATA erase to shredding

Presently should the ATA erasure operation fails, IPA halts the
cleaning process and the node goes to CLEANFAIL state as a result.

This failure could be the result of a previous cleaning failure
that left drive security enabled, for which code has been added
in an attempt to address this case by attempting to unlock the
the drive.

In the event that an operator wishes to automatically fallback to
disk scrubbing operations, the capability has been added through
a driver_internal_info field "agent_continue_if_ata_erase_failed"
that can be set to True, however defaults to False keeping the
same behavior that IPA presently exhibits in the event of ATA
erase operations failing.

subject: Apply 'if' function in resource properties and outputs sections
commit_message:
Apply 'if' function in resource properties and outputs sections

The 'if' condition can be used when property define, like:
 resources:
   server:
     type: OS::Nova::Server
     properties:
       name: {if: [condition_name, 'callmetrue', 'callmefalse']}
       ...
the name of server resource will be 'callmetrue' if condition
evaluates to true, and will be 'callmefalse' if condition
evaluates to false.

Also, the 'if' condition can be used when output define, like:
 outputs:
   test_output:
     value: {if: [condition_name, {get_attr: [my_volume]}, None]}
   ...
the 'test_output' output will show the attributes of resource
'my_volume' if the condition evaluates to true, otherwise
outputs None.

Blueprint: support-conditions-function
